newsitem.title: USA: Discovery Comms, BBC in joint venture talks - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Discovery Comms, BBC in joint venture talks - WSJ.

text.p: The British Broadcasting Corp and Discovery Communications Inc are in talks aimed at creating a joint venture to lauch television channels in the United States and abroad, and produce programming, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday.
The potential value of the joint venture is about $500 million, the Journal said, quoting anonymous sources.

Tele-Communications Inc, through its Liberty Media Corp unit, owns 49 percent of Discovery Communications. The rest is held by Cox Communications Inc, Advance/Newhouse Communications and John Hendricks, Discovery's founder, chairman and chief executive, the article said.

If successful, the deal would give the BBC its own U.S. cable-channel outlet instead of continuing to sell its programming to other outlets. The venture would also give Discovery access to the BBC's large library of programming.
Financing for the pact would come from Discovery, with the BBC's library serving as its contribution, the Journal said.
Still unclear was how the proposed venture would affect U.S. cable network Arts & Entertainment (A&E), which relies heavily on BBC proramming, the article said.
A&E is jointly owned by Walt Disney Co's ABC television network, General Electric Co's NBC television network, and the Hearst Corporation.
